title: 105_s1086
content: The "Hong Kong Reversion Act" aims to support Hong Kong's autonomous governance and well-being after its reversion to China in 1997. It outlines circumstances for the US President to modify laws if China fails to uphold Hong Kong's autonomy. The Congress findings highlight the binding international agreement between the UK and China regarding the reversion of Hong Kong in 1997. China pledged autonomy and human rights protections for Hong Kong in the agreement. Despite China's assurances of a smooth transfer of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty and the implementation of the "one country, two systems" policy, there have been official acts and statements infringing upon Hong Kong's autonomy. These include attempts to obtain confidential files on civil servants and dissolve the democratically elected Legislative Council in 1997. The Republic of China dissolved the democratically elected Legislative Council on July 1, 1997, and appointed a provisional legislature in December 1996. Officials delineated permitted speech and association types after reversion, issued initial warnings to religious institutions, and decided to repeal or amend certain Hong Kong ordinances in February 1997. Despite commitments in the Joint Declaration, there have been official acts infringing upon Hong Kong's autonomy. The Order Ordinance of 1995 and official acts of the UK Government have damaged Hong Kong's autonomy. The reversion to China has implications for US national interests. The United States Government has a responsibility to protect US interests and the human rights of the Hong Kong people during and after the transition. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 ensures the continuity of US laws regarding Hong Kong and allows the President to modify their application if Hong Kong is not sufficiently autonomous. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 aims to maintain Hong Kong's autonomy by treating it as a separate legal entity from China. The Act requires the Secretary of State to assess the implementation of the Joint Declaration, emphasizing the importance of Hong Kong's future being determined by China's government. The future of Hong Kong will be determined by China's commitment to maintain the freedoms of the people and allow them to govern themselves, as stated in the Joint Declaration. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL DECLARATIONS. Congress makes the following declarations regarding the close relationship between the United States and Hong Kong, emphasizing the importance of cooperation between their respective agencies. The United States also calls upon China to respect the autonomy of Hong Kong's customs territory and to consider the needs of United States naval vessels that historically visit the region. The United States urges China to consider US requests for port calls in Hong Kong and to respect the freedom of press and access to information in the region. Congress declares that elections in Hong Kong should be conducted according to laws approved by the people or their elected representatives, not by the provisional legislature. The United States calls on China to honor its treaty obligations under the Joint Declaration by ensuring that Hong Kong has an elected legislature. It also emphasizes the importance of upholding the essential rights and freedoms of the Hong Kong people, as outlined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The United States urges China to allow a democratically-elected legislature in Hong Kong and ensure that new legislation reflects the wishes of the people and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The United States calls on the Government of China to respect the autonomy and independence of Hong Kong's chief executive, civil service, judiciary, police, and Independent Commission Against Corruption, given Hong Kong's efficient capitalist economy and adherence to the rule of law. The United States urges China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy and institutions. Presidential determination under the US-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 and additional reporting requirements are emphasized. The President, based on assessments and reports, will consider Hong Kong's autonomy and China's actions to determine if it justifies different treatment under US law. The Secretary of State must report on the existence of a freely elected legislature in Hong Kong. The Secretary will assess whether Hong Kong has a freely elected legislature by considering the ability of people to participate in elections without restrictions on their rights. Additionally, the Secretary will evaluate the successful conclusion of agreements and treaties with the United States. The Secretary will assess Hong Kong's cooperation with the United States, including extradition treaties, consular access agreements, preservation of the U.S. consulate, mutual legal assistance, prison transfer, and civil aviation agreements. The assessment will also include evaluating cooperation in customs enforcement, drug interdiction, and prevention of money laundering, counterfeiting, credit card fraud, and organized crime. The Secretary will assess Hong Kong's autonomy, rule of law, and governance, including efforts to suppress freedom of the press and increase corruption in the government. The Secretary will assess Hong Kong's autonomy, rule of law, and governance, including efforts to suppress freedom of the press, increase corruption in the government, and misuse of the customs territory for foreign policy or trade goals. The Secretary will assess Hong Kong's autonomy, rule of law, and governance, including efforts to suppress freedom of the press, increase corruption in the government, and misuse of the customs territory for foreign policy or trade goals in the United States markets. SEC. 6 prohibits the use of funds from the United States Information Agency for any member of the Hong Kong provisional legislature to participate in its programs. The term "Hong Kong provisional legislature" refers to the body appointed in 1996 to replace the elected Legislative Council. SEC. 7 defines "Joint Declaration" as the agreement between the UK and China on Hong Kong in 1984.
